notes:
1. Definition

Electrical power is the rate at which electrical energy is transferred by an electric circuit. It is the amount of energy consumed per unit of time.

2. Formulas

The primary formula for power ($P$) is the product of voltage ($V$) and current ($I$):

$$P = VI$$

By substituting Ohm's Law ($V = IR$) into the primary power formula, two other common forms can be derived:

  • Substitute $V=IR$: $P = (IR)I = I^2R$
  • Substitute $I=V/R$: $P = V(\frac{V}{R}) = \frac{V^2}{R}$

3. Unit of Power

The SI unit of power is the watt (W), named after James Watt. One watt is defined as one joule of energy per second.

$$1 \text{ W} = 1 \frac{\text{Joule}}{\text{second}} = 1 \frac{\text{J}}{\text{s}}$$

In electrical terms, one watt is the power dissipated when one ampere of current flows through a potential difference of one volt.

$$1 \text{ W} = 1 \text{ V} \cdot 1 \text{ A}$$

solvedExamples.question: An electric heater draws 10 A of current from a 120 V source. How much power does it consume?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula $P = VI$.
$P = (120 \text{ V})(10 \text{ A}) = 1200 \text{ W}$. Note that 1.2 kW is also correct, but 1200 W is a more direct answer.

solvedExamples.question: A 100 Ω resistor has a current of 0.5 A flowing through it. How much power is dissipated as heat in the resistor?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula $P = I^2R$, which is most direct when current and resistance are known.
$P = (0.5 \text{ A})^2 (100 \; Ω) = (0.25 \text{ A}^2)(100 \; Ω) = 25 \text{ W}$.

solvedExamples.question: A light bulb is rated at 60 W when connected to a 120 V source. What is the resistance of the light bulb?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, which is best when power and voltage are known. Rearrange to solve for $R$: $R = \frac{V^2}{P}$.
$R = \frac{(120 \text{ V})^2}{60 \text{ W}} = \frac{14400 \text{ V}^2}{60 \text{ W}} = 240 \; Ω$.
